headline.main: SPERM FOUND ESPECIALLY VULNERABLE TO ENVIRONMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: AMID disputed reports that the sperm count of American men is falling, scientists are finding that a wide variety of environmental and industrial chemicals can interfere with the normal development of sperm and possibly cause birth defects and infertility. While past studies have focused almost exclusively on the mother's contribution to fetal malformations and other pregnancy abnormalities, it is now becoming increasingly clear that the father may also play an important role in pregnancy mishaps. ''The testes are very sensitive,'' said Dr. John MacLeod, retired Cornell University professor who has been studying human sperm for 30 years. ''Almost any kind of noxious chemical, if taken in enough quantity, will affect the testes.''

docs.lead_paragraph: WHENEVER Helen Lefor took out a cigarette in recent months, her husband, Arnold, would say: ''Do you realize what you're doing to me? You might be giving me emphysema! Would you please go outside to smoke.'' ''I got to know everyone in my apartment building, standing outside that way,'' said Mrs. Lefor, who stopped smoking Feb. 20. Medical research indicates that Mr. Lefor's apprehensions are not unfounded. According to the most recent report on the subject, a 14-year study conducted in Japan, wives who did not smoke but were exposed to their husbands' cigarette smoke developed lung cancer at a significantly higher rate than did the nonsmoking wives of nonsmoking husbands. Furthermore, the risk to those women was calculated to be a half to a third as great as if they themselves smoked.
